创意写作

课程编码：B15GX002Y-01 英文名称：Creative Writing 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Lewis Sandler

教学目的要求
This course introduces students to the practice of creative writing in the genres of science posters, poetry, horror fiction and science fiction. We will read and write these various genres. The aim is to make students better writers; to learn how to use your imagination in a controlled way; to dig deeper into meaning of the written word; to learn a new way of thinking/writing in English. Students will be asked to write frequently both in class and out of class.
Class Requirements
Attendance: Attendance is required. I will take attendance each class. Each unex-cused absence is minus 5 points out of 100. 5 minutes late equals one absence. Any problem with attendance will be resolved by the Department office.
Homework. There will be 4 graded homework assignments. Each assignment is 20% of 100. Participation in the class is 20% of final grade: (see B below)
There will be writing and/or reading homework each class. Homework is mandatory and is the most important part of this class and the most im-portant part of your grade. All written homework must be typed on A4 standard typing/copy paper.* Font should be Arial, Helvetica, Times, or Verdana and font size either 12 or 13 pt. (point). This handout is 13 point font size. I do not read homework that is not typed. Do not hand write your homework. (Unless I say differently.)
When typing your homework, paragraphs should be double spaced between lines (so I have space to correct it). Type name on the top right in PI-NYIN and your class number (not ID number).
Revised homework
Do not email me your homework. Most homework will be written once and revised for the next class. Only revised homework will be graded. I will tell you in advance if it will be graded. Homework is due at the beginning of the class and must be handed in when I ask for it. I do not accept late homework so do not ask me if you can give me late homework. If you know you will be absent, hand your homework to a classmate.

预修课程

主要内容

COURSE SCHEDULE ( subject to change, due to holiday schedule and class progress)
Week 1 …Intro to Creative Writing. Requirements of class, Textbooks, Creative writing and academic writing.
Week 2-4 Creative writing exercises
Week 5-8 Scary/Horror story reading and writing Tell Tale Heart by Ed-gar Allen Poe Narrator point of view writing. Create your own scary story
Week 9-11 Haiku poetry Introduction and readings (focus on concise, accurate diction and imagery of content) and create your own Haiku and present it to the class.
Week 12-16
Intro to Science Fiction reading and writing (from a list of stories by Philip K Dick to be provided later)

This lesson involves analysis of plot, point of view, descriptive vocabulary and writing your own science fiction short story.
QQ Group Class Monitor
This class needs a monitor. I will email the QQ class monitor(s) several times a week with important information about English learning, home-work and other notices. The monitor will put the email on your QQ group. You are required to read this information from the QQ group (or Wechat group) the monitor has created.
Your final grade in this class is not about your English ability.
There are 4 grades in this class. 1) Complete all the writing exer-cises, 2) Complete the Scary story exercises, 3) Complete the Haiku poetry exercises and, 4) Complete the Science Fiction story.
How to get a high score even if your English is not good:
1) Do the homework and exercises diligently and on time.
2) Ask and answer questions in class.
3) Believe in yourself.
4) Don’t be afraid to make mistakes.
5) Dare to dream the impossible.
6) Use your imagination.
My email: chinalewis@yahoo.com You may email me about any prob-lems/questions about homework or English learning. If you email me, use your own email address and sign your name in PINYIN and class number (not ID number).
My podcast. Origin of Words Podcast: online bilingual podcast for vo-cabulary and listening practice.
lewissandler.podbean.com

USB flash disk. USB闪存盘、优盘. You will need a good quality USB flash disk. I may ask you to copy your homework to the USB and connect it to the classroom computer to present your homework in front of the class . USB disk should be at least 4GB and have no viruses in it. Be sure it can connect and work properly with the classroom computer.
My style of teaching is 80-20 rule. 20% teacher lecture and the 80% student inte-raction and participation: presenting your homework in front of the class and group and partner discussions and activities in English. A noisy active class is a good class. I may ask you to read your work in front of the class. You are required to speak English in the classroom.
Plagiarism 抄袭的 抄袭 照搬
I value honesty and integrity in all homework. Do not copy homework from a book or Internet or from your classmate (or translate from Chinese to English) any material--not even one sentence. I expect all homework writing to be your own. You can do research about your homework and you can read lots of model paragraphs about the topic but you may not copy anything. Plagiarized homework receives an automatic zero. If you are not sure if your writing is plagiarism please review this website.
http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/589/02/.
If you are still not sure about plagiarism in your homework, discuss it with me before you give me your homework.

课时分配

课程思政

教材
TEXTBOOK; Required: Find the Errors, Banish Boring Words, Vocabulary Packets Bring all three to class every day. We will have exercises from some of these books time to time.
DICTIONARY, Thesaurus and Notebook
All students should have an English-English dictionary and Thesaurus . All students must have a writing notebook. We will do free writing in your notebook at the beginning of each class. You should also put new words in it every class. I may ask to see your notebook from time to time so bring it to every class. Take notes in the class in your notebook.

参考文献

课程教师信息
Lewis Sandler BS, JD, former lawyer from Boston, MA USA, teaching in China many years, UCAS instructor, podcast producer, former writer for That’s Beijing Magazine, hobbies: video, photography, science fiction and technology.

课程编码：B15GX009Y-01 英文名称：Public Speaking-I 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Mark Howard Levine

教学目的要求
As China continues to develop its connections in many fields, English Public Speaking is becoming increasingly important. The opportunity and necessity for public speaking in English are expanding in science, technology, politics, business, law, journalism, and in most fields of education. It is no longer enough to simply study English or Oral English, the time has come to develop the skills of communication both with individuals as well as large groups of people and this is what Public Speaking can help you achieve. This class will teach about the variety of types of speeches – prepared speeches where you have a longer time to prepare and impromptu where your preparation is confined to a matter of minutes. We will study how to organize your thoughts, write speeches as well as the art of delivering them to secure the maximum effect. We will deal with the different goals of speeches and the importance of focusing on those goals. Other matters to be covered include the importance of your audience, the proper use of language and appropriate use of visual aids. You will be responsible for presenting several presentations, some of which will require you to do research. Finally, you will learn the importance of time in public speaking.
Class Participation 20% – Attendance will not be taken. You are adults and ultimately responsible for your own education. But everyone is expected to be preparedAND to actively participate in all classroom activities. Obviously, if you are not in class, you will not be able to participate.
Mid-Term Speech – 30% of your mark.
Final Assignment – 50% of your mark. Visual aids can be used and may be helpful but the key to success is a well-prepared speech and delivery.

课程编码：B15GX028Y-02 英文名称：Beyond Science: Fact and Fiction 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Lewis Sandler

教学目的要求
This is a new course designed to critically analyze and explore the mysterious and strange phenomena from the past to the present and into the future. It is divided into various categories: Beyond Science News, Unsolved Mysteries, Mystical Monsters and Creatures, Myths and Legends.

This is not a passive listening course. It is designed for students who want to discuss, research and read about these phenomena in English. Students will create presentations and PPT’s to show their deep understanding of the lessons. Oral English is a requirement as well as critical thinking and deep analysis of the lessons provided.

Tentative lesson schedule subject to change and student options to create their own relevant topic)

This is not a lecture course. Students are required to interact with the teacher and with each other by making PPt’s or similar projects for each class as well as speaking English in each class

预修课程

主要内容
Week 1: Course introduction. How to critically evaluate data and online information. Area 51, about the secret United States military base. Captured aliens or alien craft at this site or a possible Russian hoax? Area 51 Homework

Week 2 Students present their ideas on Area 51 thru discussion and PPt’s.

Week 3 Creepy Urban Legends . What are they? How do they develop? True or not? from Korea, Japan and China : (The Pile of Dragons) Homework Urban Legends.

Week 4 Student PPt’s on Urban legends

Week 5 Cryptozoology.the Yetior aka Abominable Snowman True or fake?

Week 6 Student PPts on cryptozoology (The “science” of strange and mysterious animals)

Week 7 Are breatharians (only live on air) and Zombies (the biology of zombies) real?

Week 8 Student PPts on breatharians and Zombies.

Week 9 Super soldier. Is Captain America type soldier a reality? Can science create a super soldier?

Week 10 Student PPt’s on super soldier.

Week 11 Advanced Human Ancient Civilizations. Did they exist?

Week 12: Student PPT’s on advanced ancient human ancient civilizations.

Week 13 Do Qi Gong masters have super powers such as create fire or electricity from pure hands?

Week 14 Student PPt’s to prove or disprove these powers.

Week 15 Bermuda triangle aka Devils triangle (Atlantic Ocean, between Florida and Puerto Rico). What cause the disappearance of at least 75 planes and hundreds of ships over the centuries in this part of the

Week 16. Rap up of the term, Bermuda Triangle PPT’s and any other mysterious phenomenon students want to do.

课时分配

课程思政

教材

参考文献

课程教师信息
Lewis Sandler BS, JD, former lawyer from Boston, MA USA, teaching in China many years, UCAS instructor, podcast producer, former writer for That’s Beijing Magazine, hobbies: video, photography, science fiction and technology.

传媒鉴赏

课程编码：B15GX015Y-01 英文名称：Media Literacy 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Ann Marie Joan Laskiewicz-Ross

教学目的要求
In Media Literacy, the student will learn to:
1) read/view/listen and evaluate news articles, TV coverage, photos, short videos, and different media that is written or spoken in English
2) understand the different demands and restrictions on news gatherers and media distributors
3) analyze and evaluate information from contemporary media to properly formulate a written paper in English on a factual topic, using available, reliable sources.
The Media Literacy course is designed to help UCAS undergraduate students better understand the information media, which due to people’s greater literacy and the Internet, is more powerful and influential than ever before. The choices for today’s students range from established newspapers and TV to newly risen self-made bloggers, from fake news to colorful info graphics, from celebrity news to live broadcasts of disasters and war, from hour-long documentaries to news-bites that are barely a minute long.
Most classes will end with a 20 minute student-led discussion on a prearranged topic. In week 5, students will be assigned to/or chose/ a topic “beat.” In week 8 in small groups/news team, they will together begin working on one project. Individual tasks for this multimedia project will be assigned and graded at 10% for rough draft; 20% for final. Two quizzes, short writing assignments, and a final test also are part of the grade.
Attendance is mandatory. More than 3 absences for any reason mean you fail the course and receive no credit.
The English and thinking skills to be improved include greater speed in scanning print media, writing to interest readers, finding and assessing reliable sources, using academic sources, and critical thinking

预修课程

主要内容

Week
1 Introduction: What exactly is News?

2 Media coverage

3 News staff and their Beats

4 Time: Its overwhelming importance in the news field

5 Money, Eyeballs, & Shock Value: News is a Business

6 Fake News

7 Audio

8 Trends: A Nose for News

9 Limitations

10 Spin

11 Science News is Big News

12 Workshop on Small-Group Project

13 OMG—Don’t read that!

14 Review of Current News Events/Student choice

15 Is this News?

16 Conclusion

Grades:

25%- Beat Writing/journal assignments

10%- 2 Quizzes (20 min.) 5 pts. each

25%-Test

10%-Rough draft of project

20%-Final project

10%-Participation includes attendance, tardiness, homework, and preparation for student’s active engagement in classroom discussion.

课时分配

课程思政

教材
No textbook is assigned but students will be given handouts or e-material and required to read or watch specific items available from the Internet.

参考文献

课程教师信息
Prof. Ross, UCAS
Prof. Ross holds a master’s degree in communications from Columbia University and a master’s degree in education. Before beginning to teach in college and in the Pennsylvania public school system in the USA, she earned her living as a professional writer and editor.

课程编码：B15GX017Y-01 英文名称：Speaking in Academic Scenarios 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Sam Seery

教学目的要求
This module builds on the foundational English language training for second year undergraduate students at the University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. This integrated module aims to provide students with a solid foundation in academic English speaking as well as a working knowledge of the dynamics of academic scenarios.
Module learning outcomes:
On completion of this module students will be able to:
? design academic presentations
? analyse the dynamics of most academic scenarios
? understand academic etiquette
? have the confidence to engage in academic presentations
The weekly timetabled teaching will mix lectures, exercises, and interactive tutorials, but it is also expected that students will devote additional private study time to this course. The teaching summaries in this booklet give some useful reading for each session; however, you teacher will also set work for you to do outside of class times to help consolidate the materials that have been covered in class. Homework is very important and will be reviewed and discussed with teachers in subsequent weeks.

预修课程

主要内容

Week 1: Introduction, expectations, and an overview of academic scenarios

Week 2: Asking and answering questions, and academic etiquette

Week 3: Analysing non-verbal communications

Week 4: Academic roles and role play

Week 5: Debate processes and class debate

Week 6: Critical thinking and reflective practice

Week 7: Panel discussions (lecture & practice)

Week 8: Panel interviews

Week 9: Panel interviews (midterm exam)

Week 10: Presentations and critical evaluation

Week 11: Topic based projects

Week 12: Presentation week (graded group projects)

Week 13: Reflective thinking and developing a research idea

Week 14: Practical workshop (interviews)

Week 15: Rehearsals

Week 16: Feedback

To pass this module, students must attain an overall mark of at least 70%. There will be no written exam at the end of the module as there is a process of continuous assessment. There are three pieces of coursework as well as participation which combined contribute to your final mark.

The final grade will be calculated as follows:

  1. Midterm panel interview – contributes 25% towards final grade
  2. Poster presentation – contributes 25% towards final grade
  3. End of term individual interview – contributes 25% towards final grade
  4. Participation – contributes 25% towards final grade

Dates are yet to be confirmed, however; provisional dates are as follows:

  • Panel interview – week 9
  • Poster presentation – week 12
  • Individual interviews – week 16

课时分配

课程思政

教材
You are not required to purchase a textbook for this course, but as I will be using a variety of resources to provide information you will require a notebook for taking notes and preparing homework assignments.

参考文献

课程教师信息
Sam Seery – Module leader

第二外语（法）

课程编码：B15GX019Y-01 英文名称：French 课时：36 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：张旭

教学目的要求
针对法语零基础的学生，在一学期36课时之后，
1） 熟练掌握法语语音语调，熟练掌握法语基本动词的直陈式现在时变位
2） 能够进行基本的日常交流会话
3） 对法语的中级语法有了初步概念，以便日后的详细学习
课程要求
1） 法语入门相对于其他语言较难，需要有朗读及背诵法语语音及动词变位的准备及信心。
2） 从期中开始会分小组进行对话表演，需要学生能够完成简单的团队合作。
3） 需要学生对法语有兴趣，自愿学习二外法语。

预修课程

主要内容
1． 法语语音阶段 (9-12课时)：帮助学生学习最纯正的法语发音
2． 法语基础交流及会话（20课时左右，第1-10课）：学习法语基本语法及交流会话
3． 法语中级语法、时态梳理（2-4课时）：系统性完全讲解法语的所有语法及时态及变位规则，目的是让学生对法语中高级语法有最初步的认识，以便学生日后法语的继续学习。

课时分配

课程思政

教材

2014-至今 中国科学院大学外语系教师

英美文学鉴赏

课程编码：B15GX021Y-01 英文名称：British and American Literature 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：熊净雅

教学目的要求
This course is designed for non-English major undergraduate students. It aims to introduce students to classical British and American writers and literary works throughout the history. Students will enjoy themselves through reading, gain basic knowledge of British and American literary histories, know how to appreciate or criticize a literary work better, and have a taste of British and American cultures. Students will improve their English reading, speaking and writing abilities in the process.They might also develop a life-long interest of reading literatureand learn to feel sensitively and think critically to become a more complete person.This course is intended for students who are willing to devote the time and energy to read the original literary works.

预修课程

主要内容
There will be assigned readings for every given week. What will be discussed are mainly excerpts, but two or three novels in full length will be dealt with as well. In order to maximize reading comprehension, discussions, class presentations and other activities will be included.Every studentis required to write a term paper based on the works and topics discussed in class.

课时分配

课程思政

教材
1. Wang, Shouren, et al. eds. Selected Readings in British Literature. 4th ed. Beijing: Higher Education Press, 2014.
[王守仁主编：《英国文学选读》（第四版），北京：高等教育出版社，2014年。]
2. Tao Jie, et al. eds.Selected Readings in American Literature. 3rd ed. Beijing: Higher Education Press, 2011.
[陶洁主编：《美国文学选读》（第三版），北京：高等教育出版社，2011年。]
3. Jane Eyre by Charlotte Brontë
Hard Times by Charles Dickens
The Joy Luck Club by Amy Tan

参考文献

课程教师信息
Dr. Xiong Jingya is Lecturer of English at UCAS, specializing in English literature. She also lectures on public speaking in English and postgraduate English. Her recent publications include “Critic Leavis as an ‘Anti-Philosopher’ Critic: Relations among Literary Criticism, Philosophy and Literary Theory” (English and American Literary Studies 23(2015):361-372), “Leavis’s Poetic Theories Reflected by His Criticism of Eliot’s Poems” (Foreign Language Studies 35(2013):40-46).

教学目的要求
Teaching materials:
1. Professor Michael Sandel’s Justice series lectures (six weeks) at Harvard University;
Objectives: a. acquisition of academic English;
b. development of critical thinking skills;
c. familiarity with basic ethical issues.
2. The instructor’s training sessions (five weeks):
Objective: enhancement of speech-making skills.
Language requirement:
Prospective students should preferably have passed CET 6 (or an equivalent - IELTS 6.5 e.g., if not qualified yet for taking CET Band 6); or else may not be able to handle the complex discussions in class.

预修课程

主要内容

Week 1: Consequentialist moral reasoning & Categorical moral reasoning;

Week 2: Speech-making training;

Week 3: Assigning a dollar value to human life;

Week 4: Pronunciation & intonation training – British English;

Week 5: Tax on the rich to help the poor;

Week 6: Logical reasoning training I;

Week 7: Hired guns & surrogacy;

Week 8: Logical reasoning training II;

Week 9: Mid-term 1 (informative speech-making test)

Week 10: Mid-term 2 (informative speech-making test)

Week 11: Affirmative Action;

Week 12: Black Mirror & The Accused;

Week 13: Homosexual marriage;

Week 14: Speech-writing training;

Week 15: Final exam 1 (persuasive speech-making test)

Week 16: Final exam 2 (persuasive speech-making test)

教学目的要求
In this Communication Skills Training, you learn how to achieve results in your communications with others and build collaborative relationships that emphasize trust and respect. Through interactive workshops, self-assessments, role-playing activities and video simulations, you gain practical experience initiating and responding to various forms of communication. You learn to handle situations based on a flexible, genuine and self-confident approach.
on completion of this course, you will learn how to:
? Build collaborative relationships that emphasize trust and respect
? Communicate effectively using simple and concise language
? Enhance listening to anticipate and avoid misunderstandings
? Foster cross-cultural understanding in your workplace
? Eliminate communication roadblocks and focus on nonverbal cues

The weekly timetabled teaching will give you the tools to become a Master Communicator in life, love, and business.
? Master "small talk," then quickly turn it into meaningful communicating.
? Sound like an insider in any crowd — no matter how little you have in common.
? Never be stuck for something interesting to say again.
? Learn how to always look confident, credible and charismatic.
? Discover ways to talk so people listen — and listen so people talk.
? Turn social situations into professional opportunities.
? Work a convention or business gathering the way a politician works a room.
? Discover your most advantageous answer to "What do you do?"
? Learn to deal with a wide variety of personalities.
? Turn the fiercest tigers into pussycats.
? Pick up on what people are not saying – but they are thinking. Detect when someone is lying to you.
? Discern if he or she is romantically attracted to you.
? Practice "The Weekend Method" to become a more fascinating perso

课程编码：B15GX024Y-01 英文名称：Greek and Roman Mythology 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Todd Eric Neuhaus

教学目的要求
To establish a sound grasp of terms and concepts commonly accepted and practiced in the fields of literature, anthropology and cultural studies needed to construct a general framework for mythology.

Greek and Roman mythology offer insight into the world view as well as cosmological view of early Europeans. At the same time, inquiries into the origins and structures of ancient Greek and Roman mythology can serve as a point of departure to question the principles, universal norms as well as breadth of mythology worldwide. Reading and discussing the stories of specific mythological creatures or gods such as Theseus, Zeus, Jupiter or Luna amongst others serves as a point of departure for a few different kinds of insightful analysis: What function did these stories have amongst ancient people? Based on the accounts of ancient Greeks and Romans, what can we access about the cosmological as well as world view of people at the time? What symbolic and ethical details may have these stories and characters embodied? Other than historical knowledge and insight, what value may these mythologies offer to contemporary humanity?
To more fully discuss possible answers to these questions, we must also implore concrete examples of mythology. There are no limitations to cross comparison of different mythologies; however, in order to complete the task of exploring the aforementioned questions in the context of a semester long course, each week one grouping of Roman mythology as well one grouping of Greek mythology will be cross compared with one or two mythological groupings stemming from non-Roman/non-Greek cultures. This requires presentation from the point of view of the course instructor as well as input from students based on out of class review of reading materials. Each weekly lecture and in class discussion will gradually emphasize yet another series of valued questions such as: What are the most unique aspects of Ancient Roman and Greek mythology? What common effects may diverse mythologies have on members of societies? What is the importance of being knowledgeable about the world of mythology in order to understand the potential of human imagination?

预修课程

主要内容

Week 1         Orientation Week (Introduction) Drama Tragedy in Greek Plays

Week 2         World Origins/History Centered on Romans/Greeks Perspectives

Week 3         Mythological Creatures of Romans/Greeks

Week 4         The Gods of the Olympus

Week 5         The Notion of “Heroes” Jason

Week 6         Perseus

Week 7         Theseus

Week 8         Heracles

Week 9         Tests

Week 10       The Illiad Trojan War

Week 11              The Odyssy

Week 12       Athens and Sparta

Week 13       Roman Mythology Overview

Week 14       The Aeneid

Week 15       The Foundation of Rome

Week 16       Conclusion  

课时分配

课程思政

教材

参考文献
1) Tatlock, Jessie M. Greek and Roman mythology. Rockville, MD: Wildside Books, 2008. Print.
2) Additional online video QR code links will be offered on the Detailed Weekly Schedule Readout for supplemental documentary case study content.

课程教师信息

世界文学与写作

课程编码：B15GX027Y-01 英文名称：World Literature and Composition 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Ann Marie Joan Laskiewicz-Ross

教学目的要求
World Literature and Composition is designed to help UCAS undergraduate students become more informed about literary styles in English, to appreciate stories and literature, and to enjoy reading them.
We will read some recent short pieces from modern world literature and take a look at the differences in writing styles. Students will use what they learn to improve their own writing.
Since globalization and interacting with other countries will impact students’ future success, the course emphasis is on literary and cultural appreciation. That means we will be reading and reacting to stories from many different countries, a Ray Bradbury science fiction story from the US, a short story from India, some Chinese fiction, a Latin American magical realism story. (But, because this is not “a survey course,” we will not have time to read old classics, entire Shakespearean plays, or big Russian novels.)
Students will be assessed on their ability to understand the reading material (50%) and express higher level thinking (50%).

Formal Objectives: In World Literature and Composition, the student will:
1) read and comprehend short pieces of fiction written in English,
2) use writing to react to readings and to recognize how culture and personal experience shape the way a person writes,
3) analyze a literary work according to its theme,
4) increase English writing proficiency including improving overall structure and linking the ideas.
The English reading, writing and thinking skills to be improved include greater speed in scanning printed material, writing with greater clarity and higher level vocabulary, research, and critical thinking at the level of abstract ideas. Attendance is mandatory.

预修课程

主要内容

1) Introduction: What exactly is World Literature?

2) Foundations: The ‘sound’ of the alphabet.

3) Overall View: Modern world literature today

4) Meet some authors

5) Themes: We tell ourselves stories to learn how to live

6) What a character!

7) Lexical levels

8) Diversity—Meeting a new culture/ “The other”

9) Plot and what telling the plot can and cannot do

10) For some people, reading World Literature means reading a book in translation

11) Where does Chinese fiction fit in?

13) Magical Realism. When fiction is really fictional, where is the truth in it?

14) Workshop on improving your writing

15) Final themes/ Review

16) Conclusion

课时分配

课程思政

教材
Some of the reading material is available online at www.gutenberg.org at no cost to students. Students will be asked to read short works and to choose an e-novel from the course list. Students will be given handouts or e-material,and required to read or watch specific items available from the Internet.

参考文献

课程教师信息
Prof. Ross, UCAS
Prof. Ross holds a bachelor’s degree in English literature, a master’s degree in communications from Columbia University, a master’s degree in education, and a postgraduate degree in African studies including literature and history. Before beginning to teach in college and in the Pennsylvania public school system in the USA, she earned her living as a professional writer and editor. She has traveled to every continent except Antarctica. Reading fiction from the US and other countries is her lifelong hobby.

课程编码：B15GX030Y-01 英文名称：Writing for Practical Purposes 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：CARLISLE FRANCIS JAMES

教学目的要求
Module aims:
This module builds on foundational English writing learned throughout high school. This course focuses on understanding communications pathways and methods of communicating to a specific audience. During the course, participants will engage is structured debates for decision making purposes as well as consider the foundations of critical thinking and reflective practice which will enable attendees to develop their own style of communication within the workspace, through online media and in professional scenarios.
Module learning outcomes:
On completion of this module students will be able to:
? write a CV and understand the necessity for adjustment when targeting employers
? write a descriptive essay to influence decision making
? write with and without emotion
? take efficient notes for academic and professional development
The weekly timetabled teaching will mix lectures, exercises, and interactive tutorials, but it is also expected that students will devote additional private study time to this course. The teaching summaries in this booklet give some useful reading for each session. Your teacher will also set work for students to do outside of classes to help consolidate the materials that have been covered in class. Homework can be reviewed and discussed with teachers in subsequent weeks. Homework is distinct from the coursework in that homework will not be assessed though it is no less important if learning is to be consolidated.

预修课程

主要内容

Week 1: Expectations, key dates and course summary

Week 2: Note taking, shorthand, and summarising information

Week 3: Textspeak, abbreviations, and social media

Week 4: Crafting a Curriculum vitae (CV)

Week 5: Developing a professional online profile

Week 6: Emails, structure and professionalism

Week 7: Critical thinking

Week 8: Midterm

Week 9: Art and dreams

Week 10: Writing a synopsis

Week 11: Food, culture and service

Week 12: Writing a review

Week 13: Reflective thinking

Week 14: Planning a comparative essay

Week 15: Exam guidelines and practice

Week 16: Final Essay

课时分配

课程思政

教材
You are not required to purchase a textbook for this course, but as I will be using a variety of resources to provide information you will require a notebook for taking notes and preparing homework assignments.

教学目的要求
Module aims:
This module builds on foundational English writing learned throughout high school. This course focuses on understanding communications pathways and methods of communicating to a specific audience. During the course, participants will engage is structured debates for decision making purposes as well as consider the foundations of critical thinking and reflective practice which will enable attendees to develop their own style of communication within the workspace, through online media and in professional scenarios.
Module learning outcomes:
On completion of this module students will be able to:
? write a CV and understand the necessity for adjustment when targeting employers
? write a descriptive essay to influence decision making
? write with and without emotion
? take efficient notes for academic and professional development
The weekly timetabled teaching will mix lectures, exercises, and interactive tutorials, but it is also expected that students will devote additional private study time to this course. The teaching summaries in this booklet give some useful reading for each session. Your teacher will also set work for students to do outside of classes to help consolidate the materials that have been covered in class. Homework can be reviewed and discussed with teachers in subsequent weeks. Homework is distinct from the coursework in that homework will not be assessed though it is no less important if learning is to be consolidated.

预修课程

主要内容

Week 1: Expectations, key dates and course summary

Week 2: Note taking, shorthand, and summarising information

Week 3: Textspeak, abbreviations, and social media

Week 4: Crafting a Curriculum vitae (CV)

Week 5: Developing a professional online profile

Week 6: Emails, structure and professionalism

Week 7: Critical thinking

Week 8: Midterm

Week 9: Art and dreams

Week 10: Writing a synopsis

Week 11: Food, culture and service

Week 12: Writing a review

Week 13: Reflective thinking

Week 14: Planning a comparative essay

Week 15: Exam guidelines and practice

Week 16: Final Essay

课时分配

课程思政

教材
You are not required to purchase a textbook for this course, but as I will be using a variety of resources to provide information you will require a notebook for taking notes and preparing homework assignments.

课程编码：B15GX031Y-01 英文名称：Science Reading for Future Academics 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Torsten Juelich

教学目的要求
This course is designed to help students to:
understand the fundamental principles of good science-related writing;
foster weekly reading and writing activities;
learn how to read with focus on both content and grammar;
recognize patterns of good science-related writing;
develop skills required for summarizing content information;

Science Reading is a learner-centered course at the basic level to help students develop academic reading and writing skills, with focus on developing long-term skills, rather than short-term, exam-centered knowledge acquisition. During the semester, students are exposed to a wide range of articles and book chapters covering science and society. In this course, high-quality reading and writing will be fostered through students’ self-learning before and after class. In class, the teaching team focuses on fostering critical thinking and discussion of the weekly reading material, as well as analyzing content-related summary writing completed by the participating students.
Please note: this course does NOT use original research articles published in academic journals; instead, this course uses science-related texts that are easily understood by our students studying in a wide range of different disciplines.

Attendance and Participation
Active participation in class and completion of all tasks are essential to your success in this course, and play a major role in grading. Failure in completing a task will result in loss of points contributing to your final score. Importantly, it is crucial that you only take this class if you are certain that you can complete the reading required for this course.
If you are absent, it is your responsibility to come to the next class prepared. You need to contact the TA or fellow classmates to get up-to-date information about assignments you have missed. In class, you ARE allowed to use Cellphones, iPads and Computers, for the purpose of completing any task given during class. You are explicitly requested to bring science books of interest.

Academic Honesty Policy
As members of the academic community, students are expected to recognize and uphold standards of intellectual and academic integrity. Here are some basic rules that will be observed in this class and a description of the University’s honesty policy:
Cheating: Any student caught cheating on an exam or a test will be invited to leave the class and not return.
Plagiarism: Any plagiarized work will receive the grade of zero and the student will receive a warning. Students who repeatedly plagiarize texts will be invited to drop the class.
Academic dishonesty occurs in the following forms: (1) cheating on examinations, (2) plagiarism, (3) unauthorized collaboration, (4) falsification, and (5) multiple submissions.

预修课程

主要内容

Topic Weekly Focus

Week 1 Course Introduction and Overview

Week 2 Text 1:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Academic versus Non-Academic Writing

Week 3 Text 2:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

How to write a Summary

Week 4 Text 3:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Audience

Week 5 Text 4:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Organization

Week 6 Text 5:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Style (Verbs)

Week 7 Text 6:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Style (Personal pronouns)

Week 8 Text 7:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Style (Tense and Voice)

Week 9 Text 8:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Style (Run-on and contractions)

Week 10 Text 9:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Style (Figure of Speech, Idioms)

Week 11 Text 10: Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Style (Questions)

Week 12 Text 11:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Flow (Linker Phrases)

Week 13 Text 12:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Flow (Time Adverbials)

Week 14 Text 13:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Flow (Repeats)

Week 15 Text 14:  Article Analysis & Discussion + Summary Writing

Summary of Course Material

Week 16 Final Review

 

Your grade for this course will be determined as follows:

Completion of weekly reading and writing tasks:   30%

In-class participation (including weekly quizzes):  30%

In-class Presentations:       20%

Final Review:        20%

You should plan for approximately 4 hours of homework per week (2 hours preparation, 2 hours post-class analysis). Homework assignments are to be completed and turned in on the date they are due. If you miss a class, be sure to find out what assignments are due and complete them before the next class meeting so that you can turn in your homework on time.

课程思政

教材
All reading materials will be provided, no textbooks required.

心理学与生活

课程编码：B24GX003Y 英文名称：Psychology and Life 课时：30 学分：1.50 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：张兴利

教学目的要求
本课程以积极心理学视角，依据普通心理学和青年心理学的体系，联系日常生活中的心理学，系统讲述心理学中有关人的心理现象的基础研究，及人类自身活动规律及其发生发展机制。这对于学生认识自我，提高自身素质有很重要的意义。通过该课程，帮助学生了解科学心理学，促进积极正向思维，提升社会适应力，增加生活幸福度。具体收获如下：（1）了解自我，激发潜能；（3）高效学习，有所成就；（3）有效沟通，适应社会（4）正向思维，幸福生活。
本课程由教师主讲，穿插测验、小实验和小活动让学生体验互动并发现科学规律，结合“生活中的心理学”和“核心争议”展开小组研讨、总结分享，以期吸引和鼓励学生课堂积极参与，激发学生思考和分享，进而提升学生的积极心理品质和核心素养。

预修课程

主要内容
第一部分：认识自我、激发潜能

第1讲：心理学是什么？为什么要学习心理学？
四个方面来阐释这门课程，即4P：Psychology，People’s mind， Potential， Positive；
心理学的定义
心理学的起源与早期科学方法
心理学与健康
科学研究方法与健康和幸福
（心理学与生活）谁是最健康的人
（核心争议）真人秀电视节目是“真”的吗
第2讲&第3讲：人的发展&自我
人的基本属性和需要
探索人类发展，儿童发展，青少年期，成人发展与衰老
发展心理学与健康和幸福
（核心争议）父母是重要的人际关系吗
（心理学与交叉学科）发展心理学和社会心理学：为什么要交朋友
（心理学与生活）发展积极的自我认同

第二部分：高效学习、能力提升和有所成就

第4讲&第5讲：学习
学习的类型，经典条件反射、操作性条件反射、观察学习；学习的生物、文化和心理因素；
学习的认知因素：感知觉、注意、记忆、策略和学习管理
（心理学与交叉学科）知觉与社会心理学：那是枪还是手机
（心理学与生活）耳机会伤害你的耳朵吗
（心理学与生活）善用启动效应的威力
（心理学与交叉学科）记忆和知觉：为什么气味和记忆存在特殊的关系
（核心争议）记忆：被恢复的、被发明的，还是虚假的
学习与健康和幸福
（心理学与生活）智力游戏
（核心争议）严师出高徒，不打不成器？
（心理学与交叉学科）行为主义和神经科学：感觉良好是一种强化吗？
第6讲：思维、智力和语言
思维，智力和智力测验，语言及其发展理论
问题解决
（心理学与交叉学科）情绪和认知：你今天感觉怎么样，在想什么
（核心争议）：龙生龙凤生凤还是名师出高徒
第7讲：批判性思维和创造性思维
批判性思维，创造性思维
什么是批判思维和创造性思维，为什么不常批判或创造，如何提升批判性思维和创造性思维
（心理学与生活）过一种更加有创造性的生活

第三部分：有效沟通，适应社会

第8讲：人格和心理测验
巴纳姆效应，人格自测
人格的影响因素，人格与健康和幸福
（核心争议）人格是否会改变
（心理学与交叉学科）人格与情绪：有些人是否比别人更快乐
（心理学与生活）你是一个好人吗？
第9讲：情绪和情绪智力
基本情绪，积极情绪，感激
情绪智力
（核心争议）人类大脑存在识别面孔的特定区域吗
（心理学与交叉学科）情绪和神经科学：兴趣与幸福脑
第10讲：压力和动机
压力理论，科学认识压力，管理压力
动机理论，饥饿，性，超越饥饿和性：日常生活中的动机理论
（核心争议）外部动机会损害内部动机吗？
（心理学与生活）你是一个目标导向的人吗？
第11讲：社会行为
环境的力量，社会认知，亲社会行为、攻击行为和从众行为
（心理学与交叉学科）自尊能否预测攻击行为
（核心争议）电子媒体和攻击行为
（心理学与生活）掌控写作的治愈力量

第四部分：正向思维，幸福生活

第12讲：积极信念和正向思维
自我控制和坚毅：逆境vs.机遇；
刻意练习和积极信念
（心理学与交叉学科）动机与认知：我们如何抵御诱惑
第13讲：爱和幸福
亲密关系，爱和自尊，幽默与幸福，积极改变生活
心理学与健康和幸福相结合
（心理学与交叉学科）不该做的事为什么我们还要做

考核方式：
平时成绩（40%）+期末开卷考试（60%）

1.王磊 王甦等译，理查德·格里格 (Richard J. Gerrig) & 菲利普·津巴多 (Philip G. Zimbardo)著，《心理学与生活》（19版），人民邮电出版社，北京，2016
2.白学军译，罗杰·R·霍克 (Roger R.Hock)，改变心理学的40项研究(第7版)，中国人民大学出版社，北京，2015
3.王飞雪等译，劳拉·金 (Laura A.King)，普通心理学：极心理学新视角，中国人民大学出版社，北京，2013

课程编码：B24GX004Y 英文名称：The Essentials of Social Psychology 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：王詠

教学目的要求

预修课程

主要内容
教学目的和要求：
人的思想、情感和行为怎样受到真实的、想象的和隐含的他人存在的影响？人与人之间和相互作用及其心理基础如何影响我们的社会生活？我们怎么来更好地理解人们的相互关系和相互影响？如何更好地处理人际关系、良好沟通和解决冲突？
这些问题都属于社会心理学的范畴，本课程将尝试对其作出回答。课程由九个专题组成，涵盖自我概念、价值观、社会化、人际关系、沟通、爱情等社会心理学热点问题。

内容提要：
第一章 绪论：社会心理学及其发展
a) 社会心理学的界定与研究范畴
b) 社会心理学与相关学科的联系和区别
c) 社会心理学理论与主要研究方法
d) 社会心理学的发展与现状
第二章 自我概念
a) 自我与自我概念
b) 自尊
c) 文化与自我
第三章 价值取向
a) 价值取向概念及一般问题
b) 价值取向的本土化研究
c) 中国大学生价值取向
第四章 社会化与社会知觉
a) 社会化与个性化
b) 社会知觉偏差
c) 刻板印象与归因
d) 道德行为
第五章 从众、依从、服从
a) 从众：经典研究、类型、动机、条件、控制
b) 依从：原因、诱导策略、逆反心理
c) 服从：权威与服从、影响因素
第六章 人际关系
a) 人际吸引的心理基础
b) 人际关系发展过程
c) 人际关系的测量
第七章 沟通
a) 沟通的条件、过程、类型
b) 沟通障碍及改善方法
第八章 合作、竞争与冲突
a) 合作与竞争
b) 竞争心理优势
c) 冲突及其解决
第九章 爱情
a) 爱情类型与爱情三角理论
b) 罗密欧与朱莉叶效应
c) 爱情与婚姻
第十章 问与答
a) 问题解答与讨论
b) 课堂考试

教材
社会心理学（第11版）. 戴维•迈尔斯（David Myers）著，侯玉波，乐国安，张智勇 等译. 人民邮电出版社，2016年1月

考核方式
平时成绩（40%）+期末课堂考试（30%）+读书报告（30%）

预修课程

主要内容
(一）理论部分

（1）足球运动概述
① 足球运动特点与价值
②足球比赛方法与特征
（2）足球运动发展概述
① 现代足球运动发展简况
② 我国近、现代足球运动发展简况
2、专项理论
（1）足球基本技术分析
（2）足球基本战术分析
（3）足球竞赛规程
① 比赛进行及死球
② 越位
③ 犯规及不正当行为
④ 任意球
（二）实践部分
1、身体素质
（1）基本素质
（2）足球专项素质
2、基本技能
（1）足球基本技术
① 球性
● 脚的各部位推、拨、扣、拖、拉控球
● 脚背正面颠球
② 踢球技术
● 脚内侧踢地滚球技术
● 脚内侧踢空中球技术
● 脚背内侧踢球技术
● 脚背正面踢球技术

③ 接球技术　
● 脚内侧、脚底、正脚背接地滚球、反弹球

④ 运控球技术
● 脚的各部位运球
● 运球过人
⑤ 抢截球技术　
● 正面抢截球
● 侧面抢截球
⑥ 头顶球技术　
● 额正面原地、跑动头顶球


（2）足球基本战术
①个人攻防战术
● 摆脱 跑位、接应
● 策动、选位、盯人
② 局部攻防战术　
● 二过一配合
● 传切配合
③ 整体攻防战术
● 边路进攻、中路进攻
● 盯人防守、区域防守

（3）足球教学比赛及裁判
① 教学比赛
● 五人制比赛
● 七人制比赛
● 十一人制比赛
② 裁判实践　
● 裁判员哨音、手势、旗示

体育Ⅱ（网球）

课程编码：BTYGB002Y-08 英文名称：TennisⅡ 课时：34 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共必修课 主讲教师：樊菁

教学目的要求
1.目的：培养学生合作、竞争、勇敢、遵守规则等优良品质，全面提高身体素质和心理健康水平。
2.要求：穿运动服装和运动鞋，请假需提供有效证明。

预修课程

主要内容
教学内容：
1.网球运动的概述
介绍：网球的起源、网球运动的现状、网球运动的特点、网球、网球拍及场地的构造，材质
、世界重大的网球赛事。
2.学习并掌握东方式握拍方法、正手平击球技术、反手削球技术、多种基本练习方法。
学习并了解：发球技术、网前截击技术、网球比赛战略战术的原则、针对不同打法运动员的战术运用、网球运动的规则、规则在网球比赛中的灵活运用、提高身体素质的基本方法、
基本移动技术。
3.考核方式
（一）理论考试（10%）
1．网球运动概述；
2. 球运动的基本技术；
3. 网球运动的规则；
4. 体育基础理论。
（二）技术考试（20%）
评分标准：
86—100分（优秀）：技术动作正确规范、击球线路清晰、效果好，
能较高质量完成整个技术过程
76—85分（良好）：技术动作规范、击球线路无明显错误、效果较好，
能完成整个技术过程
60—75分（及格）：技术动作基本规范、某些技术动作、击球线路有
错误，基本能完成整个技术过程
59分以下（不及格）：大部分技术动作不规范、击球线路有明显错误，
不能完成整个技术过程。
（三）学习态度及综合能力评价（50%）
1.遵守纪律、诚信度。
2.自觉参与意识。
3.团结合作精神。
4.竞争意识、拼搏精神。
5.进步幅度。
（四）课堂出勤（10%）
旷课一次扣3分；事假一次扣2分；病假一次扣1分，迟到、早退一次扣0.5分。
缺勤6次及6次以上者将被取消考试资格。
（五）课外体育锻炼（10%）

体育Ⅱ（足球）

课程编码：BTYGB002Y-12 英文名称：Football Ⅱ 课时：34 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共必修课 主讲教师：于泽

教学目的要求
1.目的：培养学生合作、竞争、勇敢、遵守规则等优良品质，全面提高学生的身体素质及心理健康水平。
2.要求：穿运动服装及运动鞋，请假需提供有效证明。

预修课程

主要内容
(一）理论部分
1、基础理论
（1）足球运动概述
① 足球运动特点与价值
②足球比赛方法与特征
（2）足球运动发展概述
① 现代足球运动发展简况
② 我国近、现代足球运动发展简况
2、专项理论
（1）足球基本技术分析
（2）足球基本战术分析
（3）足球竞赛规程
① 比赛进行及死球
② 越位
③ 犯规及不正当行为
④ 任意球
（二）实践部分
1、身体素质
（1）基本素质
（2）足球专项素质
2、基本技能
（1）足球基本技术
① 球性
● 脚的各部位推、拨、扣、拖、拉控球
● 脚背正面颠球
② 踢球技术
● 脚内侧踢地滚球技术
● 脚内侧踢空中球技术
● 脚背内侧踢球技术
● 脚背正面踢球技术

③ 接球技术　
● 脚内侧、脚底、正脚背接地滚球、反弹球

④ 运控球技术
● 脚的各部位运球
● 运球过人
⑤ 抢截球技术　
● 正面抢截球
● 侧面抢截球
⑥ 头顶球技术　
● 额正面原地、跑动头顶球


（2）足球基本战术
①个人攻防战术
● 摆脱 跑位、接应
● 策动、选位、盯人
② 局部攻防战术　
● 二过一配合
● 传切配合
③ 整体攻防战术
● 边路进攻、中路进攻
● 盯人防守、区域防守

（3）足球教学比赛及裁判
① 教学比赛
● 五人制比赛
● 七人制比赛
● 十一人制比赛
② 裁判实践　
● 裁判员哨音、手势、旗示

考核方式：综合评价

体育Ⅱ（网球）

课程编码：BTYGB002Y-13 英文名称：Tennis Ⅱ 课时：34 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共必修课 主讲教师：刘铁军

教学目的要求
1.目的：培养学生合作、竞争、勇敢、遵守规则等优良品质，全面提高学生的身体素质及心理健康水平。
2.要求：穿运动服装及运动鞋，请假需提供有效证明。

预修课程

主要内容
教学内容：
1.网球运动的概述
介绍：网球的起源、网球运动的现状、网球运动的特点、网球、网球拍及场地的构造，材质
、世界重大的网球赛事。
2.学习并掌握东方式握拍方法、正手平击球技术、反手削球技术、多种基本练习方法。
学习并了解：发球技术、网前截击技术、网球比赛战略战术的原则、针对不同打法运动员的战术运用、网球运动的规则、规则在网球比赛中的灵活运用、提高身体素质的基本方法、
基本移动技术。
3.考核方式
（一）理论考试（10%）
1．网球运动概述；
2. 球运动的基本技术；
3. 网球运动的规则；
4. 体育基础理论。
（二）技术考试（20%）
评分标准：
86—100分（优秀）：技术动作正确规范、击球线路清晰、效果好，
能较高质量完成整个技术过程
76—85分（良好）：技术动作规范、击球线路无明显错误、效果较好，
能完成整个技术过程
60—75分（及格）：技术动作基本规范、某些技术动作、击球线路有
错误，基本能完成整个技术过程
59分以下（不及格）：大部分技术动作不规范、击球线路有明显错误，
不能完成整个技术过程。
（三）学习态度及综合能力评价（50%）
1.遵守纪律、诚信度。
2.自觉参与意识。
3.团结合作精神。
4.竞争意识、拼搏精神。
5.进步幅度。
（四）课堂出勤（10%）
旷课一次扣3分；事假一次扣2分；病假一次扣1分，迟到、早退一次扣0.5分。
缺勤6次及6次以上者将被取消考试资格。
（五）课外体育锻炼（10%）

课程思政

教材

课程教师信息
孙科，男， 1981年9月出生，博士后，讲师，清华大学体育部，国家二级运动员，主要从事排球教学工作。研究方向为体育史、体育传媒，先后主持国家级课题1项，省部级课题2项；在《体育科学》、《体育学刊》、《体育与科学》、《北京体育大学学报》等CSSCI期刊发表论文8篇；参与国家社科基金5项、省部级课题3项；参与获得教育部人文社科优秀成果三等奖、全国体育新闻传播会议论文报告一等奖。

4）投篮——行进间单手上篮技术
5）“一传一切”的战术配合

体育Ⅳ（网球）

课程编码：BTYGB004Y-10 英文名称：Tennis Ⅳ 课时：34 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共必修课 主讲教师：刘铁军

教学目的要求
1.目的：培养学生合作、竞争、勇敢、遵守规则等优良品质，全面提高身体素质及健康的心理。
2.要求：穿运动服装和运动鞋，请假需提供有效证明。

预修课程

主要内容
教学内容：
1.网球运动的概述
介绍：网球的起源、网球运动的现状、网球运动的特点、网球、网球拍及场地的构造，材质
、世界重大的网球赛事。
2.学习并掌握东方式握拍方法、正手平击球技术、反手削球技术、多种基本练习方法。
学习并了解：发球技术、网前截击技术、网球比赛战略战术的原则、针对不同打法运动员的战术运用、网球运动的规则、规则在网球比赛中的灵活运用、提高身体素质的基本方法、
基本移动技术。
3.考核方式
（一）理论考试（10%）
1．网球运动概述；
2. 球运动的基本技术；
3. 网球运动的规则；
4. 体育基础理论。
（二）技术考试（20%）
评分标准：
86—100分（优秀）：技术动作正确规范、击球线路清晰、效果好，
能较高质量完成整个技术过程
76—85分（良好）：技术动作规范、击球线路无明显错误、效果较好，
能完成整个技术过程
60—75分（及格）：技术动作基本规范、某些技术动作、击球线路有
错误，基本能完成整个技术过程
59分以下（不及格）：大部分技术动作不规范、击球线路有明显错误，
不能完成整个技术过程。
（三）学习态度及综合能力评价（50%）
1.遵守纪律、诚信度。
2.自觉参与意识。
3.团结合作精神。
4.竞争意识、拼搏精神。
5.进步幅度。
（四）课堂出勤（10%）
旷课一次扣3分；事假一次扣2分；病假一次扣1分，迟到、早退一次扣0.5分。
缺勤6次及6次以上者将被取消考试资格。
（五）课外体育锻炼（10%）
